Shape: A medium-sized ternlike seabird with very long wings and an outsized bill in which the lower mandible is much longer than the upper.
Compared Size: Larger than a Laughing Gull, slightly smaller than a Royal Tern (but with longer wings).

description: Starkly black above and white below, with black-and-red bill and orange-red legs. Juveniles are brownish above, with pale-edged wing covert feathers.

Skimmers have a distinctive flight style: usually very low to the water, with long upstrokes but short downstrokes to stay clear of the water. This creates a characteristic bounding or ranging style to the flight.
Coastal beaches and islands near oceans or Gulf of Mexico; occasionally seen inland, especially in sites such as Salton Sea, California, and Palm Beach County, Florida.
Black Skimmers in North America have a dark tail with white outer feathers. In parts of Brazil through Argentina, the subspecies intercedens has a brown tail.
